Based on her early‐stage, polyp‐associated T1 disease (stage IIA at worst), negative imaging through age 55.9, normalized CEA levels, receipt of standard adjuvant FOLFOX, and the absence of high‐risk molecular features (e.g. MSI stable, modest TMB), the likelihood of recurrence in the ensuing 9 months is low. 

[ANSWER: B) No]

Based on the patient’s successful resection of isolated liver metastasis at age 57.17, her return to ECOG 0–1, persistently normal/slightly elevated CEA levels (≤2.2 ng/mL), and serial CT scans through age 57.77 showing no further progression while on standard FOLFOXIRI chemotherapy, her performance status and disease control are favorable. The one‐year overall survival after resection of a solitary colorectal liver metastasis with adjuvant chemo typically exceeds 70–80%. Thus it is very likely she will remain alive over the next 12 months.

[ANSWER: A) Yes]

Based on her solitary‐metastasis resection at 57.17 years, adjuvant FOLFOXIRI, and a clean scan at 57.77 years, the one‐year disease-free survival rate after isolated colorectal liver metastasis resection still hovers around 50–60%. Thus it remains more likely than not that the cancer will progress within the next 12 months.

[ANSWER: A) Yes]
